v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[Authentication Without MFA]: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds an extra layer of authentication assurance beyond traditional credentials. With MFA enabled, when a user signs in to the AWS Console, they will be prompted for their user name and password as well as for an authentication code from their physical or virtual MFA token. It is recommended that MFA be enabled for all accounts that have a console password. Enabling MFA provides increased security for console access as it requires the authenticating principal to possess a device that displays a time-sensitive key and have knowledge of a credential.

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 29, a result was found. 'The attribute(s) 'policy.Statement.Condition' or/and 'policy.Statement.Condition.BoolIfExists' or/and 'policy.Statement.Condition.BoolIfExists.aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent' is/are undefined or null', but 'The attributes 'policy.Statement.Condition', 'policy.Statement.Condition.BoolIfExists', and 'policy.Statement.Condition.BoolIfExists.aws:MultiFactorAuthPresent' are defined and not null'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[IAM Access Key Is Exposed]: AWS console defaults to no check boxes selected when creating a new IAM user. When cerating the IAM User credentials you have to determine what type of access they require. Programmatic access: The IAM user might need to make API calls, use the AWS CLI, or use the Tools for Windows PowerShell. In that case, create an access key (access key ID and a secret access key) for that user. AWS Management Console access: If the user needs to access the AWS Management Console, create a password for the user. Requiring the additional steps be taken by the user for programmatic access after their profile has been created will give a stronger indication of intent that access keys are [a] necessary for their work and [b] once the access key is established on an account that the keys may be in use somewhere in the organization. Note : Even if it is known the user will need access keys, require them to create the keys themselves or put in a support ticket to have them created as a separate step from user creation.

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 21, a result was found. ''aws_iam_access_key[user].user' is '${aws_iam_user.user.name}' for an active access key', but ''aws_iam_access_key[user].user' is 'root' for an active access key'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[CMK Rotation Disabled]: AWS Key Management Service (KMS) allows customers to rotate the backing key which is key material stored within the KMS which is tied to the key ID of the Customer Created customer master key (CMK). It is the backing key that is used to perform cryptographic operations such as encryption and decryption. Automated key rotation currently retains all prior backing keys so that decryption of encrypted data can take place transparently. It is recommended that CMK key rotation be enabled. Rotating encryption keys helps reduce the potential impact of a compromised key as data encrypted with a new key cannot be accessed with a previous key that may have been exposed.

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 1, a result was found. 'aws_kms_key[logs_key].enable_key_rotation is undefined', but 'aws_kms_key[logs_key].enable_key_rotation is set to true'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[Unrestricted Security Group Ingress]: Security groups should restrict ingress only to well-known and allowed origins: IP addresses or ranges. Unrestricted access may expose security groups associated resources to the Internet, allowing, for example, access to remote server open ports. Public access to remote servers increases the resource attack surface and unnecessarily raises the risk of resource compromise.

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 88, a result was found. 'One of 'ingress.cidr_blocks' equal '0.0.0.0/0'', but 'One of 'ingress.cidr_blocks' not equal '0.0.0.0/0''

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[EBS Volume Encryption Disabled]: Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) supports encryption at rest when using the Elastic Block Store (EBS) service. While disabled by default, forcing encryption at EBS volume creation is supported. Encrypting data at rest reduces the likelihood that it is unintentionally exposed and can nullify the impact of disclosure if the encryption remains unbroken.

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[Using Default Service Account]: Instances must not be configured to use the Default Service Account, that has full access to all Cloud APIs, which means the attribute 'service_account' and its sub attribute 'email' must be defined. Additionally, 'email' must not be empty and must also not be a default Google Compute Engine service account.

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 3, a result was found. ''google_compute_instance[server].service_account' is undefined or null', but ''google_compute_instance[server].service_account' is defined and not null'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[ECR Image Tag Not Immutable]: ECR should have an image tag be immutable

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 3, a result was found. 'aws_ecr_repository.repository.image_tag_mutability is 'MUTABLE'', but 'aws_ecr_repository.repository.image_tag_mutability is 'IMMUTABLE''

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[ECR Repository Not Encrypted]: ECR (Elastic Container Registry) Repository encryption should be set

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 1, a result was found. 'The attribute 'encryption_configuration' is undefined or null', but 'The attribute 'encryption_configuration' is defined and not null'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[Unscanned ECR Image]: Checks if the ECR Image has been scanned

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 1, a result was found. 'aws_ecr_repository[repository].image_scanning_configuration is undefined', but 'aws_ecr_repository[repository].image_scanning_configuration is defined'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[ECR Repository Without Policy]: ECR Repository should have Policies attached to it

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 1, a result was found. 'aws_ecr_repository[repository] doesn't have policies attached', but 'aws_ecr_repository[repository] has policies attached'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[ElasticSearch Not Encrypted At Rest]: Check if ElasticSearch encryption is disabled at Rest

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 1, a result was found. ''encrypt_at_rest' is undefined', but ''encrypt_at_rest' is set and enabled'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[Elasticsearch Domain Not Encrypted Node To Node]: Elasticsearch Domain encryption should be enabled node to node

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 1, a result was found. 'The attribute 'node_to_node_encryption' is undefined', but 'The attribute 'node_to_node_encryption' is set to true'

v:vulnerability.v:description: [Terraform].[Elasticsearch Domain With Vulnerable Policy]: Elasticsearch Domain policy should avoid wildcard in 'Action' and 'Principal'.

v:recommendation.Recommendation: In line 42, a result was found. 'aws_elasticsearch_domain_policy[monitoring-framework-policy].access_policies has wildcard in 'Action' or 'Principal'', but 'aws_elasticsearch_domain_policy[monitoring-framework-policy].access_policies does not have wildcard in 'Action' and 'Principal''
